channel.title: NPR Topics: Culture
channel.description: Art and entertainment commentary plus interviews, book reviews, movie reviews, music reviews, comedy, and visual art. Subscribe to podcasts and follow trends in music, painting, art, architecture, photography, and design.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: In Berlin, there are movies, there's politics and there's talk about it all
item.description: Buzz around whether the city's film festival would take a stance on the war in Gaza has dominated conversation in recent days.
item.content:encoded:
Buzz around whether the city's film festival would take a stance on the war in Gaza has dominated conversation in recent days.

(Image credit: John MacDougall)
item.dc:creator: Teresa Xie

item.title: '10% Happier' author Dan Harris talks about a moment of kindness from a stranger
item.description: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. 10% Happier author Dan Harris talks about a moment of kindness from a stranger.
item.content:encoded: On Wild Card, well-known guests answer the kinds of questions we often think about but don't talk about. 10% Happier author Dan Harris talks about a moment of kindness from a stranger.

item.title: On pins and needles: Why Olympians pass the time knitting
item.description: A number of Olympic athletes have turned to knitting during the heat of the Games, including Ben Ogden, who this week became the most decorated American male Olympic cross-country skier.
item.content:encoded:
Right: Bronze medallist USA's Jessie Diggins celebrates on the podium for the women's cross-country 10km. Both Olympians knit during their downtime between events.'/>

A number of Olympic athletes have turned to knitting during the heat of the Games, including Ben Ogden, who this week became the most decorated American male Olympic cross-country skier.

(Image credit: Anne-Christine Poujoulat)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: Facing a mental health crisis, an NJ school pulled a beloved novel from English class
item.description: Junot Díaz's The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao was removed from an English class at the public school. PEN America says it's part of a trend of scrubbing literature dealing with uncomfortable topics.
item.content:encoded:
The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao from the curriculum of a high-level English class at Columbia High School in Maplewood, N.J., in response to a mental health crisis.'/>

Junot Díaz's The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao was removed from an English class at the public school. PEN America says it's part of a trend of scrubbing literature dealing with uncomfortable topics.

(Image credit: Anastasia Tsioulcas)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Remembering filmmaker Frederick Wiseman
item.description: Wiseman's narration-free documentaries, including Titicut Follies, Hospital and Central Park, examined institutions and neighborhoods. He died Feb. 16. Originally broadcast in 1986.
item.content:encoded: Wiseman's narration-free documentaries, including Titicut Follies, Hospital and Central Park, examined institutions and neighborhoods. He died Feb. 16. Originally broadcast in 1986.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: Remembering Oscar-winning actor Robert Duvall
item.description: Duvall, who died Feb. 15, often played intense, combative characters. His film credits include The Godfather, Apocalypse Now, The Great Santini and Lonesome Dove. Originally broadcast in 1996 and 2010.
item.content:encoded: Duvall, who died Feb. 15, often played intense, combative characters. His film credits include The Godfather, Apocalypse Now, The Great Santini and Lonesome Dove. Originally broadcast in 1996 and 2010.
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross

item.title: What I learned watching every sport at the Winter Olympics
item.description: Sit down with pop culture critic Linda Holmes as she watches the 2026 Winter Games. She is exhausted by cross-country, says "ow ow ow" during moguls, and makes the case, once and for all, for curling.
item.content:encoded:
Sit down with pop culture critic Linda Holmes as she watches the 2026 Winter Games. She is exhausted by cross-country, says "ow ow ow" during moguls, and makes the case, once and for all, for curling.

(Image credit: Gabriel Bouys)
item.dc:creator: Linda Holmes

item.title: Internal memo details cosmetic changes and facility repairs to Kennedy Center
item.description: Trump announced his plans to close the Kennedy Center entirely for two years "for Construction, Revitalization, and Complete Rebuilding." The announcement came after many prominent artists canceled existing scheduled appearances.
item.content:encoded:
Trump announced his plans to close the Kennedy Center entirely for two years "for Construction, Revitalization, and Complete Rebuilding." The announcement came after many prominent artists canceled existing scheduled appearances.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Tsioulcas

item.title: Reporter's notebook: My Olympic Lunar New Year
item.description: An NPR reporter covering the Olympics in Milan takes us on cultural side quests, to a hospitality house and a candy store.
item.content:encoded:
An NPR reporter covering the Olympics in Milan takes us on cultural side quests, to a hospitality house and a candy store.

(Image credit: Rachel Treisman)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman

item.title: Michael Pollan says AI may 'think' — but it will never be conscious
item.description: "Consciousness is under siege," says author Michael Pollan. His new book, A World Appears, explores consciousness on both a personal and technological level.
item.content:encoded:
"Consciousness is under siege," says author Michael Pollan. His new book, A World Appears, explores consciousness on both a personal and technological level.

(Image credit: Christopher Michel)
item.dc:creator: Terry Gross
